Department of Chemical Engineering, King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals Dhahran Saudi Arabia Novel Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 was investigated for ODH of propane to propylene using CO2 as a mild oxidant in a batch scale fluidized CREC Riser Simulator. La2O3 in the catalysts provided a control of both the reducibility and acidity, as shown by H2-TPR and NH3-TPD, respectively. The propane conversion and products selectivity were strong function of La2O3 content in the Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 catalysts. With increasing La2O3 content in the catalyst, propane conversion dropped slightly but the propylene selectivity and yields increased. It was proposed that the presence of La2O3 reduced the non-selective sites and the acidity of the catalysts, that contributed towards deep oxidation of propane and propylene. The improved activity and selectivity with CO2 addition implied that the as-synthesized catalyst possesses CO2 activation capability required for ODH reactions. Among the investigated catalysts, Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3(1:1) exhibited the highest propane conversion (92 %) and propylene yield (56 %) at 600 ℃ in the presence of CO2. Graphical Abstract Keywords Gallium oxide Propane Carbon dioxide Propylene Mild oxidant Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene is an essential organic chemical considered as a building block for the synthesis of several key industrial products such as polypropylene, acrolein, acrylic acid and other relevant chemicals we use in our daily life [1,2]. The growing global demand for propylene, at an annual growth rate of 5 %, is going to touch approximately 0.2 billion tons by the end of this decade i.e., 2030 [3,4]. In order to cope with the increasing propylene demand, the synthesis of propylene in an efficient way becomes vital. Conventionally, propylene is produced via steam cracking of naphtha, and refinery-based fluid catalytic cracking, etc. However, these processes lead to lower propylene selectivity even at elevated temperature conditions [2,4,5,6,7,8]. Propylene synthesis using propane dehydrogenation is one of the efficient and green routes that has gained scientists’ attraction because of the abundant propane supply after the shale gas technology development [9,10]. The dehydrogenation of propane encompasses the direct propane dehydrogenation [DPH, Eq. (1)] and the oxidative propane dehydrogenation [OPDH, Eq. (2) and Eq (3)] routes. DPH serves as an economically viable process for propylene production and is also commercially adopted by KBR-licensed Superflex, UOP-licensed Oleflex technologies, etc. [11]. However, the utilization of platinum- and/or chromium-based expensive catalysts has significant environmental implications [12]. The oxidative route with O2 [O2-OPDH, Eq. (2)], a non-equilibrium limited exothermic reaction, offers several substantial advantages [2,11,13,14]. Despite significant progress in O2-OPDH, it is still challenging to avoid olefin over-oxidation due to the stronger oxidative nature of oxygen [15]. To overcome and/or minimize the olefin over-oxidation problem, the concept of utilizing a moderate oxidant such as carbon dioxide (CO2) as a replacement of oxygen has introduced the oxidative route of CO2-OPDH [Eq. (3)] [43]. Climate change and global warming require CO2 capture and utilization since CO2 is one of the major greenhouse gases [15,16,17,18]. However, CO2 activation, due to its thermodynamic stability [19], is a difficult task and therefore, the development of an effective catalyst with the capability to produce propylene from CO2-OPDH is highly desired. (1) C 3 H 8 ↔ C 3 H 6 + H 2 ∆ H 298 0 = + 125 KJ / mol (2) C 3 H 8 + 1 / 2 O 2 ↔ C 3 H 6 + H 2 O ∆ H 298 0 = − 118 KJ / mol (3) C 3 H 8 + CO 2 ↔ C 3 H 6 + CO + H 2 O ∆ H 298 0 = + 164 KJ / mol Chromium-based catalysts, due to their high activities, are still preferably utilized in CO2-OPDH [20,21,22]. However, as mentioned earlier chromium is not only toxic but also detrimental to the environment. Hence, the discovery of an efficient chromium-free catalyst is desirable. Numerous chromium-free catalysts such as Mo2C, [26], MoO3/La2O3-γAl2O3 [43], Pd/CeZrAlO x [4], Fe-doped CeO2 [27], ZnO/HZSM-5, [12] WO x -VO x /SiO2 [23], In/HZSM-5 [25], In2O3-O x [24], and Ga2O3–Al2O3, [28] etc., have been reported for their good catalytic performances. Gallium (Ga), among the above-mentioned catalysts, is found to be a potential replacement for the harmful Chromium. Gallium oxide (Ga2O3)-based catalysts have been investigated for CO2-OPDH [28] and CO2-OEDH (where E represents ethane) [29,30]. Moreover, depending upon Ga species, Ga facilitates C–H activation [31] which in turn improves the propylene selectivity. The development of oxidative catalyst suitable for light alkane dehydrogenation requires a) the redox characteristics i.e., the activity and selectivity is a function of the lattice oxygen species of the catalyst and molecular oxygen species of an oxidizing agent are less effective, b) the presence of isolated active sites which facilitates minimizing the products oxidation [32]. The choice of an appropriate support material improves the activity and durability of a metal oxide-based catalyst. Among the oxide supports including alumina (Al2O3), silica (SiO2), and titania (TiO2), Al2O3 offers promising textural and mild acidic characteristics suitable for redox active metal catalyst. However, phase transformation and sintering at elevated temperatures are the drawbacks of Al2O3 [33–35]. In order to cope with the drawbacks associated with Al2O3 i.e., to enhance the activity and thermal stability, a secondary metal oxide such as cerium, lanthanum, and/or zirconium can be incorporated to γ-Al2O3 [34,36]. Lanthanum oxide or lanthana (La2O3) is found to be an outstanding material that promotes the basic properties of the catalyst [37]. Furthermore, lanthana incorporation also improves the metal dispersion, specific surface area of the catalyst, catalyst fluidizability, thermal stability, catalyst reducibility, CO2 adsorption capacity, and the acidic properties of the support [38–41]. Xu et al. [42] investigated the role of different oxide supports such as Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, SiO2, and MgO for Ga2O3-based catalysts during OPDH with and without CO2 and found that SiO2- and MgO-supported Ga2O3 catalysts remained inactive while the rest of the supports showed propane conversions in the absence of CO2. The addition of CO2 promoted the catalytic activities of Ga2O3/Al2O3, Ga2O3/TiO2, and Ga2O3/ZrO2 catalysts. The acid-base properties and metal-support interaction were found to play the major role in influencing the propane conversions. The modification of Al2O3 with lanthana for the Ga2O3-based catalyst system is not reported earlier for CO2-OPDH. This research work evaluates the role of Ga2O3 and La2O3 in Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of propane using CO2 as an oxidant. The effect of CO2 presence, reaction temperature, and ratio of γ-Al2O3 to La2O3 are also discussed. Catalyst samples before and after the reaction were characterized by TGA and XRD to relate the phase composition to the activation behavior and catalytic performance, and a mechanism is proposed to describe the role of Ga2O3 and La2O3 in the activation process. 2 Experimental section The coprecipitation technique was used to synthesize the catalyst support. The Ga was deposited on the support by means of the incipient wetness impregnation technique. All the chemicals employed in the synthesis of the catalyst were obtained from commercial source and for this matter were used without any further purification. The following chemicals were used: Al(NO3)3.9 H2O as Al2O3 precursor, La(NO3)3.6 H2O as La2O3 precursor and Ga(NO3)3·H2O as Ga2O3 precursor and (NH4)2CO3 as pH control and a precipitating agent. 2.1 Synthesis of support materials The La2O3-γAl2O3 composite support was prepared by a coprecipitation technique as described in our previous work [42,43]. The desired quantity of metallic nitrates precursors of lanthanum (La(NO3)3.6 H2O) and aluminum (Al(NO3)3.9 H2O) were dissolved in deionized water. A buffer solution of ammonium carbonate ((NH4)2CO3) was added to maintain a pH of 8.5 to generate precipitates at about 40 ℃ with continuous stirring. The formed precipitate was aged for 2 h at 100 ℃, dried at 120 ℃ for 2 h and then calcined at 600 ℃ for 6 h [44]. The series of catalyst support were synthesized by varying the mass ratio of lanthanum to aluminium as follows: La:Al= 1:1, 1:2 and 1:3. The three series of composite supports were identified as La2O3-γAl2O3 (1:1), La2O3-γAl2O3 (1:2) and La2O3-γAl2O3 (1:3). A reference γAl2O3 support was synthesized using the same procedure with zero lanthanum incorporation. 2.2 Deposition of active site on support Gallium was wet impregnated over the surface of the support. Stoichiometric quantity, corresponding to 10 wt%, of hydrated gallium nitrate (Ga(NO3)3·H2O) was added in DI water in accordance with the support’s total pore volume followed by addition of the support to the solution [45]. The system was subjected to continuous magnetic stirring for 3 h followed by drying at 120 ℃ for 6 h and subsequent calcination at 750 ℃ for 6 h under instrument-grade air flow [46]. The resulting catalyst was identified as Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3, Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:3), Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:2), Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:1). The detail catalyst synthesis steps were summarized in the flowchart in Figure S1 of the Supplementary Information. 2.3 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The XRD characterization was conducted to categorize the relative concentration of the crystalline phases present in the Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 catalysts. In this regard, a Mini-Flex II bench-top XRD machine purchased from Rigaku equipped with a copper (Cu-Kα) radiation source (λ=0.15406 nm) was used at a voltage of 40 kV and a current of 30 mA. For each sample, a 2θ scanning range of 10 – 90° with a 0.02 step size and scanning rate of 3°/min were utilized. The phase identification of the samples was achieved by comparing the recorded diffraction data of the samples with the JCPDS (Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards) files. 2.4 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) The FTIR characterization technique uses infrared spectrum of transmission absorption as well as photoconductivity via a substance either in liquid or solid state. This technique enables us to determine the functional groups/species and their characteristics on the support surfaces. The FTIR analysis was performed by means of Nicolet 6700 Series by Thermo Fisher Scientific. Each analysis required a mixture of around 3 mg of the catalyst and 400 mg KBr in the form of a uniform blend. The results from the FTIR were recorded in between 400 and 4000 cm−1 of spectrum. 2.5 Scanning electron microscope-energy dispersive X-ray (SEM-EDX) Analysis The SEM-EDX analysis was conducted to determine and analyze the surface morphology of the synthesized catalyst with different metal loading. The SEM analysis was carried out on a JEOL-SEM analyzer. The elemental composition of the catalyst samples was determined by EDX analysis. In this regard, the powder sample was spread on a copper covered stump. To ensure proper analysis and high quality, the gold-coated sample was used, and the image was magnified a million times. All the measurement was conducted and at ambient temperature. 2.6 Textural properties analysis The BET specific surface area and the porosity of the prepared catalyst samples were established by using the Micromeritic model ASAP analyzer. The N2 adsorption-desorption analysis was done using an estimated amount of 300 mg. The catalyst pretreatment i.e., degassing was carried out at approximately 473 K, under vacuum, for 2.5 h to do away with any form of wetness and undesired impurities. The N 2 adsorption process was executed in a bath containing liquid nitrogen to maintain the temperature at about 77 K and a relative pressure range of 10−6 to 1. The surface area was evaluated using Multiple point BET, whiles the BJH (Barrett, Joyner, and Halenda) was used in obtaining the pore volume [47]. 2.7 NH3-TPD An Autochem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer purchased from Micromeritics Inc. was utilized to analyze the acidity of the synthesized catalyst using ammonia TPD. The analysis is done by packing approximately 0.1 g of the catalyst in between cotton wool in a U- tube quartz shape reactor which is then fitted to the sample port. The sample was reduced under 10 % H 2 in He , at a temperature of about 500 ℃ followed by degassing using argon for 2 h at the same temperature and then cooled down to 100 ℃. The catalyst was flooded with ammonia (5.52 % NH 3 balanced with 94.48 % helium) at 100 ℃ flowing at 50 ml/min for 1 h. Subsequently, any leftover ammonia was removed from the system by flowing (500 ml/min) helium at 100 ℃. The temperature of the system was raised to 750 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃/min whiles the desorption of the chemisorbed ammonia on the catalyst was being monitored using a TCD detector in the effluent gas [48]. 2.8 H2-TPR The H2-TPR (Temperature Programmed Reduction) experiment was carried out to study the reducibility of the Ga2O3 supported on La-Al binary oxide catalyst in a H2 environment. The H2-TPR analysis was conducted with the Micrometrics Autochem II 2920 equipment. The TPR experiment was used to determine (i) the Ga/support interaction (ii) the H2 uptake by Ga2O3 and (iii) the reduction/activation temperature. About 10 mg of the catalyst sample pack in between a glass wool in a quartz U-tube shape reactor, which was then mounted on the equipment. The sample was initially treated to get rid of volatile contaminants and traces of H2O by flowing argon at 500 ℃. The treated catalyst was then subjected to oxidation in a stream of 5 % O2 balance with Helium at 750 ℃ for about an hour. A 10 %H2 in Helium mixture was subsequently flown through the catalyst sample at a flow rate of 50 ml/min whiles simultaneously increasing the sample temperature from ambient to 850 ℃ at 10 ℃/min heating rate. The amount of H2 consumed by the sample was determined using a calibrated TCD detector. The results from the experiment was presented as a plot of amount H2 consumed versus reduction temperature or time. The area under the H2-TPR curve is proportional to the amount of H2 consumed. 2.9 TGA The Thermo-gravimetric Analysis (TGA) was conducted to assess the thermal stability of the catalysts and to quantify the possibility of coke formation during the propane ODH using CO2 as mild oxidant. The spent catalyst sample were collected after their evaluation in the CREC Riser Simulator at different temperature. In this regard, an SDT Q600 analyzer (TA Instruments) was employed. For each analysis 10 mg of spent catalyst sample were taken to the sample pan and carefully placed into the TGA furnace. The coke combustion (oxidation) experiment were conducted by circulating air (95 ml/min). The weight loss data was recorded up to 800 ℃ at 10 ℃/min heating rate. 3 Propane ODH with carbon dioxide The CO2-assisted propane ODH experiments using Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 catalyst were conducted in a fluidized-bed chemical reaction engineering center (CREC) Riser Simulator reactor [49,50]. The details of the fluidized CREC Riser Simulator and the experimental setup are presented in Figure S2 of the Supplementary Information. The ODH runs were conducted by using approximately 0.2 g of the synthesized catalyst. Impurities were fluxed out of the system by passing argon gas and a leak test was also done. The leak test was carried out by raising the reactor pressure up to about 30 psi at ambient temperature. A stable pressure reading when the reactor is isolated indicates that the reactor is leak free. When no leak is detected, the temperature of the reactor is progressively increased to the desired reaction temperature. For the prevention of any oxygen interference, the reactor was constantly purged with argon gas. As the required pressure is approached, the reactor section is isolated from the vacuum section by a valve. With the aid of a vacuum pump, the pressure of vacuum box was reduced to about 3 psi while keeping the reactor pressure at atmospheric pressure. Propane ODH with CO2 was the executed by first injecting a 4 ml carbon dioxide into the reactor by a syringe. The catalyst bed was then fluidized with the help of an impeller placed at the top of the reactor basket and operating at about 4500 rpm. At this moment, 2 ml propane was injected into the fluidized bed by an airtight syringe. The ratio of C3H8:CO2 used was 1:2. The 4-PV spontaneously opens when the specified reaction time reached. This allows the formed product to be transported into the vacuum box instantaneously and prevents further reactions from occurring in the reactor. With the aid of the 6-VP, the product gas mixture was injected in to the online GC (Agilent 7890 A) for analysis. The online GC is equipped with a TCD (6Ft 1/8 2 mm HayeSep Q 80/100 Ni) to detect CH3, CO, CO2 and H2 and the flame ionization detector (FID) (HP AL/S (8 μm) analytical column: 25 m × 0.32 mm) which detects CH4, C2H6, C2H4, C3H8, C3H6 and other hydrocarbons [51]. At the end of each reaction, the products were transferred to the GC and analyzed. The catalyst was then regenerated for 10 mins at 600 ℃ and at a mixing rate (impeller speed) of 5000 rpm in the presence air to burn off the coke deposit on the catalyst. (4) Propane conversion , X C 3 H 8 ( % ) = ∑ j z j n j 3 n propane + ∑ j z j n j × 100 (5) Selectivity to a product , S j ( % ) = z j n j ∑ j z j n j × 100 (6) Y i % = ( X C 3 H 8 × S i ) / 100 where, n j is the moles of j in product and, z j its number of carbon atom. n propane is unconverted propane (mole). 4 Results and discussion 4.1 XRD analysis Fig. 1 display the XRD pattern of the bare γ-Al2O3, Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 with different lanthanum oxide loading of 0, 25, 33.3 and 50 wt%. The bare γ-Al2O3 curve exhibits trio of characteristic peaks at two-theta values of 37.5, 45.5 and 67° (JCPDS 10–425), respectively [52–54,57–59]. The shoulder peaks around 39.5ᵒ is attributed to γ-Al2O3 phase as it can be found in the Al2O3 support. The intensity of the three peaks, attributed to pure γ-Al2O3, remained unaffected by the deposition of Ga2O3 on γ-Al2O3. Moreover, a very weak shoulder at about 19ᵒ was detected in sample Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3 may be attributed to the presence of ꞵ-Ga2O3. This observation indicates that either gallium oxide is well dispersed over the surface of alumina support and/or the particle size of gallium oxide is below the detection limit of XRD [22,23]. It is obvious that lanthanum oxide incorporation into alumina influenced the crystalline structure and noticeable decrease in the peak intensities at 2θ values of 37.5, 45.5 and 67° for all the catalyst samples was observed [58]. This may be attributed to the decrease in the particle size/crystallinity of γAl2O3 or due to partial coverage by La2O3. The appearance of a new broad peak located at 2θ angle of 30° from samples containing lanthanum oxide is assigned to crystalline La2O3 [61,62]. It is interesting to note that no peaks associated with the formation of LaAlO3 are observed in contrast to what has been reported earlier [55,56] for lanthanum oxide loading higher than 10 wt%, which can be assigned to lower calcination temperature in this study. 4.2 SEM-EDX analysis The images from the SEM micrographs and the data from the energy dispersive X-ray analysis EDX of the synthesized catalyst are displayed in Fig. 2. The SEM images displays the surface morphology whiles the EDX depicts the elements on the surface of the catalyst. One can observe that all the catalyst samples containing La2O3 under investigation are made up of particles that are rough and irregular in shape and size just like the pure γ-Al2O3. This observation shows that the morphology of the γ-Al2O3 was not altered by the incorporation of lanthanum oxide. This confirms the fact there was insignificant interaction between the lanthanum oxide and the support. The deposition of gallium over the catalyst support is confirmed by the data obtained from EDX analysis as gallium was not present on the bare γAl2O3 in Fig. 2e as expected. Furthermore, the results from the EDX show that the elements present in the γAl2O3 sample (Fig. 2a) were only Al and O while Ga was the extra element present in sample Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3. In the same way, La and Ga were the additional elements found in the rest of the synthesized samples (Fig. 2c & d). In summary, the Fig. 2 micrographs indicate the successful incorporation of lanthanum and gallium oxide over the γ-Al2O3 catalyst support. The carbon present in the EDX graph is an impurity that was introduced during sample preparation for the analysis. This successful incorporation of lanthanum and gallium oxide could improve the active site and contact area for efficient performance of the catalyst during the propane ODH reaction [60]. 4.3 Specific surface area and porosity analysis The isotherms based on volume of nitrogen adsorbed with respect to relative pressure of all the samples under investigation is presented in Fig. 3a. It can be observed that all the catalyst samples exhibited similar shape. The shape could be described as type IV isotherms with the H2-type hysteresis loop at a relative pressure range of 0.5–0.9. This is an indication that the synthesized material is mesoporous in nature with the bottleneck like pore with wider bodies. The average pore size distribution (displayed in Fig. 3b) of the samples were found to be approximately 8.0 nm which falls within the IUPAC range of 2–50 nm. This further confirms that the material synthesized is mesoporous [61]. The summary of the physicochemical parameters including the BET surface area (SA), total pore volume (PV), and average pore diameter (PD) is found in Table 1. The N2-adsorbtion isotherm were used in determining the BET surface area of the catalyst samples. From Table 1, the catalyst with the highest surface area (193 m3/g) is the sample with zero La2O3 content, Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3. The incorporation of La2O3 in the support decreased the total surface area in the order 131.5, 92.2 and 44.0 m3/g corresponding to Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:3), Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:2) and Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:1) respectively. One can notice that the total surface area of the sample decreased as the amount of La2O3 incorporated in the support increases. The total pore volume of the catalyst sample also decreased as the quantity of La2O3 in the support increases. The shrinkage of in the surface area could be attributed to lanthanum oxide penetrating and blocking the bottleneck-like mesopore of the support. The enhancement in average pore size distribution further validated this observation and variations in the average pore diameter were noted from 7.12, 7.52, 8.01–12.06 nm for Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3, Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:3), Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:2) and Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:1) respectively based as the La2O3 content. Remarkably, some researchers found that the incorporation of about 3–5 % lanthanum oxide in γ-Al2O3 support increases the catalyst’s specific surface area [62,63]. Nonetheless, in our study, we observed that the addition of more than 10 % lanthanum oxide in a γ-Al2O3 results in the decrease in the catalyst surface area. Lu et al. [64] also reported similar findings where they established that the amount of lanthanum oxide plays a role in affecting the textural characteristics of the catalyst. 4.4 Acidity by NH3-TPD In order to obtain insight into the surface acidity of the catalyst samples, the NH3-TPD experiment was conducted and reported in Fig. 4. The sample with zero lanthanum oxide loading exhibited low temperature characteristic peaks and/or shoulders with maximum peak temperatures at 170 and 270 ℃ as well as a high temperature narrow peak centered at 595 ℃ corresponding to the desorption of physisorbed ammonia species at the moderate/weak and strong acid sites respectively [65]. The rest of the catalyst samples with lanthanum oxide incorporation display two low-intensity low temperature desorption peaks/shoulders centered around 150–160 ℃ and ∼270–310 ℃ respectively, along with a high temperature desorption broader peak with maximum peak temperature at ∼640–645 ℃ corresponds to the desorption of adsorbed NH3 at weak, moderate and strong acid site respectively. It is obvious that desorption profiles shift towards higher temperature with incorporation of lanthanum oxide. Interestingly, the area under the NH3-TPD curve at lower temperature which correlates to the amount of weak/moderate acid site decreases with an increase in lanthanum oxide contents. However, the area under the curve at high temperatures region relating to the desorption of physisorbed NH3 at the strong acid site increases with increasing amount of lanthanum oxide. This behavior can be assigned to the existence of coordinated ion of La3+ functioning as a Lewis acid site. In this situation, the cation, La3+ could be responsible for the acid site density dynamics [66,67]. In general, the total acidity of the catalyst samples under investigation slightly decreases as the quantity of La2O3 incorporated in the support increased as can be seen from Table 2. This suggests that the lanthanum oxide could be responsible for the reduction of acid site on the catalyst sample [68,69]. The decline in the acid site is attributed to pore adjustment due to the La2O3 incorporated, resulting in pore entrance blockage as observed in the N2 adsorption/desorption analysis in agreement with previous reports [66,69]. Moreover, the promotional impact of La2O3 incorporation on enhancing the basic sites over catalyst surface are well known and that also contributed to reduced acidity of the catalysts [69]. 4.5 H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) The hydrogen-based temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) provides an insight into the catalyst reduction/activation temperature and the degree of metal-support interaction which ultimately influences the catalytic performance. In the case of CO2-assisted propane ODH, H2-TPR becomes important given that the catalyst can actively participate in the redox mechanism using lattice oxygen [12]. H2-TPR provides the degree of reduction of the catalysts and the amount of lattice oxygen available for reaction. Fig. 5 shows the TPR results of Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3, Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:3), Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:2), and Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:1). The peak intensity of the sample Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3 without La2O3 content is the lowest among the four series of catalysts. This catalyst exhibited one small peak at around 125 ℃ followed by two major peaks centered at approximately 405 and 575 ℃, and a small peak at 765 ℃, respectively. Previous studies suggested that the reduction of gallium oxide (Ga2O3) gives gallium suboxide (Ga2O) according to Ga2O3 + 2 H2 → Ga2O + 2 H2O [70], although a different support material was used. The peak for the reduction of Ga2O3 to Ga2O was not detected in the La2O3 containing samples. In this regard, one can imagine that the small amount of Ga2O3 that is present in the Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 catalysts migrates/made homogeneous mixture with La2O3-γ-Al2O3 particles, therefore no separate peak was appeared due to it reduction. The La2O3 containing Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:3), Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:2) and Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:1) catalyst displayed all the reduction peaks at lower peak temperatures i.e., first peak shifted to around 105 ℃ for all the lanthanum oxide incorporated catalysts, the second peak disappeared while third peaks shifted to 495, 490 and 490 ℃, and the fourth small peak shifted to approximately 755 ℃ for all the lanthanum oxide incorporated catalysts, respectively. The area under the reduction peaks increased as the La2O3/γ-Al2O3 ratio (the La2O3 contents) increases in the samples, indicating hydrogen consumption due to additional La2O3 reduction. The decrease of the reduction peak temperature with an increase in the La2O3/γ-Al2O3 ratio (the amount of La2O3) indicates that La2O3 facilitated the reduction of the catalyst which also reflected by the increase of the area under the TPR-profiles. This behavior is consistent to our previous study on the reduction of NiO/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 catalysts, which showed La interacts more readily with the alumina support, inhibiting the complex formation and provide better metal dispersion/re-dispersion [71]. Consequently, there was a shift of reduction peak maxima to a lower temperature with La incorporation. The shift of the reduction peak could be assigned to the various sizes of La2O3 forming over the catalyst surface. Generally, the smaller particles lead to lower reduction temperatures [72]. The role of Ga2O3 in this H2-TPR experiments were not clear given all the samples contains same amount of Ga. However, previous studies showed that the presence of Ga3+ ions in Ga2O3-γAl2O3 plays important roles in reduction of oxidation of other species present in the catalyst [73]. 4.6 Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis is utilized in the investigating of the surface chemical bonding of the synthesized materials. This technique enables us to determine the characteristics of the functional groups present on the support. The functional groups are identified by the bending motion or stretching in the chemical bonds that exist in the metal oxide [74]. The FTIR of γ-Al2O3, Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3 and Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 with different lanthanum loading is displayed in Fig. 6. As one can see, all the catalyst samples display similar vibrations as γ-Al2O3. This may be attributed to weak interactions between the Al2O3 and La2O3 as also observed in the SEM results. The broad band at 3500 cm−1 and the narrow band at 1630 cm−1 are attributed to the bending vibration mode of O-H and the stretching vibration of H-O-H due to the water molecule weakly adsorbed on the catalyst support [74,75]. It can be observed that the vibration at about 3600 cm−1 reduces as the amount of lanthanum content in the catalyst support increased. The observation may point to the fact that lanthanum reduces the hygroscopic nature of the catalyst by making available more active sites for reaction (in this case desired oxidative dehydrogenation of propane to propylene). The broad peak between 500 cm−1 and 1000 cm−1 displays strong absorption which is assigned to the vibration mode of oxides of Al (Al-O) [76]. 4.7 CO2-assisted catalytic propane oxidative dehydrogenation The propane ODH tests were carried out with Ga2O3/ γAl2O3 and Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 catalysts in a fluidized CREC Riser Simulator using CO2 as a mild oxygenate. The catalytic evaluation tests utilized approximately 0.2 g of the fresh catalyst subjected to various temperatures between 500 and 600℃ at a residence time of 30 s. The product stream mainly contains ethylene and propylene, however, methane (CH4), ethane (C2H6), CO and CO2 are also found as the minor products. In order to demonstrate reliable and reproducible results, all experiments were conducted at least in triplicates. The calculated propane conversion and product selectivity in the experimental repeats are found to be within 3.5 % standard deviations. The measurement of carbon balance was based upon all major and minor products as mentioned above and the deposited carbon over the surface of the catalyst was found to be within ± 6.5 %. To evaluate the impact of CO2 during propane ODH, a series of separate three experimental tests were conducted - a) propane ODH with a single propane injection both in the presence and absence of CO2, and re-oxidization of catalyst using air at the end of each run, b) propane ODH with multiple injections in the absence of air i.e., no catalyst regeneration. This set of experiments facilitated to identify CO2 role in affecting product selectivity as well as in-situ regeneration of the catalyst, hence, the successive propane injection was used for complete reduction of the catalyst, and finally c) propane and CO2 were co-fed over pre-reduced catalysts in order to determine the role of CO2 in re-oxidizing the catalyst, converting propane as well as affecting product selectivity. The propane ODH/DDH experiments with a single injection are also categorized i.e., i) propane DDH in the absence of CO2 – to evaluate reaction/re-oxidation cycles of Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 pre-oxidized catalysts during their interaction with propane, ii) investigating reaction/regeneration cycles during CO2-assisted propane ODH to examine reactants interaction with each other and with fully oxidized catalyst. 4.7.1 ODH/DDH of C3H8 with and without of CO2 Fig. 7 compares the propane ODH over Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3 with and without CO2, we can observe that the catalyst performance is more enhanced in the CO2 environment. This is an indication that the CO2 plays a significant role in influencing the catalytic performance of the Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The propane conversion and propylene yield over Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in the presence of CO2 was 65 % and 37 % respectively as compared with 44 and 22 % respectively in the absence of CO2 at the same reaction temperature of 575 ℃. Fig. 8 presents a similar observation where the addition of CO2 to the dehydrogenation reaction over Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:1) records higher propane conversion (65 %), propylene yield (40 %) and propylene selectivity (62 %) as compared to the dehydrogenation in the absence of CO2 with corresponding propane conversion of 37 %, propylene yield of 13 %, and propylene selectivity of 36 %. The presence of CO2 helped to minimize the further cracking of produced propylene. Consequently, the ethylene selectivity is decreased and propylene selectivity increased. In the presence of CO2, most of the active sites responsible for the secondary conversion of propylene into other products (such as ethylene) are being occupied by CO2. In other words, there is competitive adsorption between propylene and CO2. A small amount of (less than one percent) of (unconverted) CO2 was detected as part of the products of the dehydrogenation reaction in the presence of CO2 indicating that the continuous removal of hydrogen via reverse water gas shift (RWGS) and re-oxidation of the reduce catalysts, both contribute to enhanced catalytic performance [1]. 4.7.2 Effects of reaction temperature on CO2-assisted propane ODH The oxidative dehydrogenation with CO2 is an endothermic reaction (Eq. 3), therefore one can expect the increase of equilibrium propane conversion with temperature. On the contrary, the oxidative dehydrogenation with oxygen/metal oxide the reaction is exothermic (Eq. 2). Also, there are contributions due to the other series parallel reactions. The overall effects on propane conversion and products selectivity will depend on the dominating reactions. In the context of present study, one can consider three major roles of CO2 with the: (i) influence on the thermodynamic equilibrium of the complete oxidation reactions to minimize CO2 formation (Eqs. 7–9), (ii) direct interaction with propane to give propylene (Eq. 10), and (iii) re-oxidizing the oxygen depleted catalysts (Eq. 12). In addition, CO2 may also contribute to dehydrogenation of propane by converting hydrogen via reverse water gas shift reaction and oxidize carbon by Boudouard reaction. All these contributes to increase propylene conversion and propylene selectivity. (7) Complete oxidation of propane : C 3 H 8 + 10 MO x ↔ 3 CO 2 + 4 H 2 O + 10 MO x − 1 (8) Complete oxidation of propylene : C 3 H 6 + 9 MO x ↔ 3 CO 2 + 3 H 2 O + 9 MO x − 1 (9) Complete oxidation of ethane : C 2 H 6 + 7 MO x ↔ 2 CO 2 + 3 H 2 O + 7 MO x − 1 (10) ODH of propane to propylene with CO 2 : C 3 H 8 + CO 2 ↔ C 3 H 6 + H 2 O + CO (11) Reverse water − gas shift reaction : CO 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O (12) Catalyst re − oxidation with CO 2 : MO x − 1 + CO 2 ↔ CO + MO x (where, MOx refers to catalyst metal oxides) The catalysts also have an important role on the complex interplay between the main CO2-ODH reaction and the other side reactions. Therefore, in it important to investigate the effects of reaction temperature on both the propane conversion and products selectivity. Fig. 9 presents the propane ODH results in terms of conversion, yield and selectivity of both the Ga2O3/γAl2O3 and Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 catalysts. The conversion data shows that propane conversion increased linearly with respect to temperature for all the tested catalysts. For example, Ga2O3/γAl2O3 catalyst exhibited a propane conversion of 16 % at 525 ℃ that reaches to 62 % with increase in the reaction temperature to 600 ℃. The H2-TPR results in Fig. 7 indicated the presence of lattice oxygen and the activation of this lattice oxygen at higher ODH temperature plays a role in enhancing propane conversion with respect to temperature for all the tested catalysts. Moreover, the activated lattice oxygen interaction with propane (C-H bond) converts it to both major and minor products. C-H bond activation, reported to be a rate limiting step in propane ODH [77], was also promoted due to higher reaction temperatures facilitating enhanced propane conversion. The La containing catalyst Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 displayed relatively higher conversion of propane at desired range of reaction temperatures in comparison with the Ga2O3/ γAl2O3 catalyst. These findings are consistent with the reduction profiles of Fig. 7 where the Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 catalyst has demonstrated easier reduction in contrast to Ga2O3/γAl2O3 catalyst. This implies that the Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 catalyst can easily activate C-H bond due to its higher lattice oxygen capacity. However, the difference of propane conversion at higher temperature (575–600 ℃) is less significant. This may be attributed to contribution of possible thermal cracking of propane. In addition to lattice oxygen, textural properties such as specific surface area also plays a role in influencing the catalytic performance during propane ODH. The specific surface area results in Table 1 indicate that La incorporation has negatively affected the specific surface area of Ga2O3/γ-Al2O3 and this decrease in specific surface area is also one of the factors behind lower propane conversions at the higher amounts of La. The reduction in specific surface area leads to reduced number of active sites for adsorption of propane during propane ODH. The role of La incorporation and its contents in reducing hydrocarbon conversions during propane ODH is also reported elsewhere [78,79]. 4.7.3 Catalyst stability under successive C6H8 injection with and without CO2 The experiments with successive propane injection were performed by subjecting the Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 (1:1) catalyst to consecutive propane injection in the CREC Riser Simulator. The ODH experiment was performed for about ten consecutive reactions without the catalyst regeneration in between reactions. The first eight reactions were carried out over the catalyst by injection only propane as the feed in each reaction. At the 9th and 10th injections, CO2 was added to the propane feed. The ratio of C3H8 to CO2 in the 9th and 10th reactions were 1:2 and 1:3 respectively. The results of successive experiments are summarized in Fig. 10. The initial propane conversion over the fresh catalyst in 1st reaction was around 38 %. The propane conversion then declined progressively to 30 %, 27 % and 23 % in the 2nd,3rd and 4th injection. The propane conversion dropped further to 20 % at fifth reaction and remained constant up to the 8th reaction. The propylene selectivity increased gradually from 35 % in the 1st reaction to around 45 % in the 8th reaction. The decline in the propane conversion and propylene yield may be attributed to the carbon deposition on the gallium catalyst [80]. As a result of the CO2 addition, the propane conversion increased to 26 % and 45 % at the 9th and 10th reaction respectively. Again, the propylene selectivity was also improved as a result of the CO2 incorporation. The increase in the conversion of propane and selectivity of propylene could be assigned to a) hydrogen removal by the CO2 via RWGS reaction that shifts reaction 1 equilibrium towards product side leading to enhanced selectivity of propylene, b) the elimination of secondary reaction by improved propylene desorption from catalyst surface, c) the role of the reverse Boudouard reaction in removing carbon formed over the catalyst surface [81,82]. 4.7.4 Nature of spent catalyst after evaluation The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were used to study Ga2O3/La2O3-γ-Al2O3 catalysts after CO2-assisted propane ODH. XRD profiles of spent catalysts in Fig. 11 exhibit similar diffraction patterns of fresh catalysts. This suggests that no structural variations in the catalysts were noticed during CO2-assisted propane ODH. TGA was utilized to assess the catalyst stability with respect to coke deposition during CO2-assisted propane ODH as shown in Fig. 12. It is obvious from TGA curve that major weight loss was observed at a temperature below 180 ℃ that could be ascribed to elimination of moisture adsorbed over the catalyst surface [3]. The absence of weight loss at higher temperatures (> 180 ℃) demonstrates no formation of carbon during CO2-assisted propane ODH. This was consistent with no COx detection via GC during catalyst regeneration. 5 Conclusion This work examined the catalytic CO2-assisted propane ODH using mild oxidant over Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 catalysts that were synthesized, characterized before and after reaction, and tested in a fluidized-bed Riser Simulator. The following points are the conclusion of this work: I. The textural properties analysis of as-synthesized catalysts showed that the catalysts have mesoporous nature with an H2 type hysteresis loop having a bottleneck-like pore with wider bodies as well as a minimum average pore size of 8 nm. II. The La addition had negative impact on the specific surface area of the catalysts mainly associated with pore blockage by La incorporation. III. The reduction profiles indicated that La-free Ga2O3/γAl2O3 catalyst exhibited reduction of gallium oxide while single-step reduction profiles of Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 catalysts suggest the presence of largely homogeneous reducible species. Moreover, La addition improved Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 catalyst reducibility. IV. The acidity measurement by NH3-TPD demonstrated that La-free Ga2O3/γAl2O3 catalyst had both weak and strong acid sites. However, La incorporation reduced the number of weak acid sites while enhanced strong acid sites. Moreover, the amount of NH3 uptake increased with La incorporation only for strong acid sites (high-temperature acidity). V. Regardless of reaction temperature, the relatively higher propane conversion of Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 (1:1) catalyst during propane ODH was attributed to higher number of reducible species of this catalyst. VI. The CO2-assisted propane ODH showed that the mild oxidant not only promoted its interaction with hydrocarbon feed but also re-oxidized the pre-reduced catalyst, hence improved both the conversion, yield and selectivity. VII. The CO2 molecules introduced with the feed (and also produced) compete for the active sites, which are mainly responsible for complete oxidation of the produced olefins. Consequently, the presence of CO2 (adsorbed) facilitated non-selective site masking that contributed in improved selectivity towards olefins. CRediT authorship contribution statement Mohammed S. coredata.dc:description: Novel Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 was investigated for ODH of propane to propylene using CO2 as a mild oxidant in a batch scale fluidized CREC Riser Simulator. La2O3 in the catalysts provided a control of both the reducibility and acidity, as shown by H2-TPR and NH3-TPD, respectively. The propane conversion and products selectivity were strong function of La2O3 content in the Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3 catalysts. With increasing La2O3 content in the catalyst, propane conversion dropped slightly but the propylene selectivity and yields increased. It was proposed that the presence of La2O3 reduced the non-selective sites and the acidity of the catalysts, that contributed towards deep oxidation of propane and propylene. The improved activity and selectivity with CO2 addition implied that the as-synthesized catalyst possesses CO2 activation capability required for ODH reactions. Among the investigated catalysts, Ga2O3/La2O3-γAl2O3(1:1) exhibited the highest propane conversion (92 %) and propylene yield (56 %) at 600 ℃ in the presence of CO2.
